textbooks.title: Value Proposition Design: How to Create Products and Services Customers Want
textbooks.author: Alexander Osterwalder, Yves Pigneur, Gregory Bernarda, Alan Smith, Trish Papadakos

topics: Entrepreneurship in the light of economic theory
Integrating the Value Proposition into the Business Model Canvas
The Role of the Entrepreneur & IP
Analyzing the specific situations of entrepreneurs
Business Plan Analysis & Business Idea Pitch
Presentation & Discussion of Business plan issues

grading.policies: Assignments received 1-6 days late will have 20% of the total points deducted; assignments received more than one week late will receive 0 points.

assignments.name: Class Participation
assignments.description: Participation in weekly class discussions via online discussion boards on Canvas. Each student will submit at least two postings per week.

assignments.name: Venture Business Idea Analysis
assignments.description: Analyze a venture business idea with the Value Proposition Canvas. Individual assignment.

assignments.name: Lean Business Plan
assignments.description: Team effort to deliver a lean business plan. Team consists of max. three students.

assignments.name: Elevator Pitch
assignments.description: Presentation of the business idea must be no longer than a 3 minutes pre-recorded presentation.

assignments.name: Midterm Exam
assignments.description: Online midterm exam covering the first 7 weeks of the course.

policies.attendance: Class attendance is recorded for every lecture.
policies.late_work: Assignments received 1-6 days late will have 20% of the total points deducted; assignments received more than one week late will receive 0 points.
policies.academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work.
policies.accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

additional_info.course_format: This course is offered fully online.
additional_info.technology_requirements: Basic computer and web-browsing skills, navigating Canvas, live web conferencing using Zoom, recording a slide presentation with audio narration, recording, editing, and uploading video via Panopto.
additional_info.support_resources: For more information about course access or support, contact the Technology Resource and Assistance Center (TRAC) by calling 201-216-5500.

instructor.name: Frank Gallucci
instructor.office_hours: By appointment, Virtual Office Hours are held Wednesday from 4:30 – 6:30 pm ET.

_metadata.course_description: This course is offered for students who seek to understand the process of creating and developing business opportunities within organizations or who want to initiate and create their own venture.
learning_outcomes: Contrast small business ideas from entrepreneurial business ideas by applying basic economic principles.
Assess entrepreneurial business opportunities with a set of comprehensive evaluation criteria entirely and differentiate between attractive and non-attractive business opportunities.
Apply frameworks to transform an entrepreneurial business idea into a complete and viable venture idea.
Communicate entrepreneurial business ideas by applying basic principles of business pitch development.
